Students will write a short proposal following the guidelines for proposals in our honours program.  The proposals will provide a short background on the topic, highlight the significance of the research, and outline the proposed methodology.  The student's academic supervisor will provide written feedback.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d330a85bdbe5f450be4672f5f39619ce","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5b30a85bdbe5f450be4672f5f39619d4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research seminar","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

contentlets.keywords: biological,earth & environmental science
contentlets.description:
Short theoretical or experimental research project, supervised by a member of academic staff. The research project may encompass project planning, literature review, project development, fieldwork, experimental work, statistical analyses and oral and written
reporting. Projects may also involve ‘placements’ outside UNSW, in the form of externally funded research programs, industrial placements or other programs either during usual session or in the session breaks. In these cases students will require an academic member of staff to supervise the internship. Note: This course is restricted to students undertaking a Major in the School of BEES. Enrolment in this course is by invitation and subject to availability of places: interested students should contact a suitable supervisor and the Director of Teaching.
contentlets.title: Special Program in Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences - Undergraduate 6 units of credit

honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"BEES0010","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEES0010 - Australian Environment, Wildlife and Conservation","description":"

NOTE: This course is only available to Study Abroad students, i.e it is not available to students enrolled in a degree program at UNSW. It is held for 6 weeks in June / July each year. To be eligible to enrol, students must be enrolled in an undergraduate program at an accredited university, with a minimum 2.8 GPA. This 6 week short course is specifically designed for International students. The program provides a unique opportunity to consider human impacts on the natural environment, and measures to address these impacts, focusing particularly on protected conservation areas. Australia provides a valuable and unique case study in this regard. The course is contextualised within the global ecological crisis and considers the development of environmental values and awareness and describes environmental controversies and how they are addressed. In consideration of these issues, Australia's unique flora and fauna are examined and the various climatically varied regions visited are highlighted throughout the course.The program outlines and exposes students to the challenges in managing natural and cultural heritage in the 21st century. There is a strong emphasis on Aboriginal perspectives of the Australian landscape and its importance to this ancient culture. The program will familiarise participants with the spiritual and ecological ties of Aboriginal culture with the landscape and how this is incorporated in management of national parks.

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEES1041 - Exploring the Natural World","description":"

The course will introduce students to the science and scientific methods within the life, environmental and Earth sciences. In particular, the course will introduce students to the research undertaken in the School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences (BEES) and its application to contemporary environmental problems, management and issues. The aims of the course also include a focus on employment options within the disciplines covered by BEES and the potential pathways within our Majors to give students the best opportunities to achieve their career aspirations. The course also focuses on skills including relevant quantitative techniques, methods for collecting environmental data including new technologies, sampling and experimental design, methods for visualising environmental information (graphics, mapping) and communicating results. 


Note: The course includes a non-compulsory but recommended field trip. Participation requires a valid passport and will involve expense to individuals.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5040e85bdbe5f450be4672f5f3961997","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Practical exercise 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will be assessed on their ability to undertake simple analyses (e.g. covered in MATH1041), consider hypotheses and to present data in a logical and clear manner. Conclusions supported by the data will be expected and content regarding science communication will be assessed. This assignment is due at the end of week 5.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9040e85bdbe5f450be4672f5f3961999","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9840e85bdbe5f450be4672f5f3961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9840e85bdbe5f450be4672f5f3961999","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1440e85bdbe5f450be4672f5f396199b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam will cover all aspects of the material in the course.  The exam will assess students' general understanding of the main approaches to exploring the natural world, and how these methods relate to a broader understanding to environmental problems and contribute to effective environmental managements.  The exam will take place in the scheduled exam period at the end of the term.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9040e85bdbe5f450be4672f5f3961999","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9040e85bdbe5f450be4672f5f396199a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1c40e85bdbe5f450be4672f5f39619d1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Report 2: Communicating results","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

Report 2 will assess the ability of students to effectively communicate the results of an environmental sampling program or experiment. They will be required to provide the three elements needed for results sections in scientific reports: written descriptions of results, figures that illustrate results and appropriate analyses to support findings. This report is due at the end of week 8.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9040e85bdbe5f450be4672f5f396199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9840e85bdbe5f450be4672f5f3961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9840e85bdbe5f450be4672f5f3961999","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1c40e85bdbe5f450be4672f5f39619d7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Report 1: New technologies in environmental sampling","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Report 1 will involve assess the principles of sampling and experimental design for the environmental sciences. Students will need to find examples of new technologies involved in environmental research, explain their use and design a sampling program for a current environmental issue. This assignment is due at the end of week 3, so that it can be assessed and returned before the census date.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9040e85bdbe5f450be4672f5f3961999","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5440e85bdbe5f450be4672f5f39619d5","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/BEES1041.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Feedback from academic staff is provided within two weeks of submission, in the form of marks and written comments.

contentlets.keywords: biological,earth & environmental science
contentlets.description: Development of skills in applying statistics to biological, earth and spatial data; design and analysis of experiments in life and earth sciences; sampling strategies for estimating sample size; analysis of community and environment structure using multivariate statistics; simulation modelling in population biology, and statistical fitting of non-linear models to population growth data; correlation and both simple and multiple regression; improving statistical models using analysis of residuals; analysis of spatial data.Examples are drawn from ecological, geographical, earth, behavioural, genetic, microbial and immunological data. Practical work emphasises problem-solving and hands-on experience with EXCEL, MINITAB and other specialist software.Assumed Knowledge: MATH1041
contentlets.title: Data Analysis for Life and Earth Sciences

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEES2051 - Work Integrated Learning Placement","description":"

This Work Integrated Learning (WIL) Placement course enables students to work at a partner organisation in an area of Biological, Earth or Environmental science. It is designed to enable students to extend and deepen their academic knowledge of their discipline and their personal and professional skills, capabilities and employability. Students are required to spend approximately 140 hours at their partner organisation, during which time they will work under the supervision of their workplace supervisor. Additional time will be required for students to complete a preparatory online module before commencing as well as two online modules during their placement as well as formal assessment tasks. Some of these tasks can be completed during their work placement hours.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"617020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961910","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Student Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will write a structured report of 2000 words on their personal and professional development throughout the course/placement including: personal and professional strengths and limitations and what is required in the future to improve these capabilities. Students will describe what they have learned about the nature of the partner organisation and the work place skills and knowledge they have gained. Students will also be asked to describe the positive and negative experiences of their placement and how this has, or has not, influenced their opinion of the workplace and their interests in the related field/topic. 

Students will receive feedback asap after submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e17020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961911","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e17020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961912","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e17020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e97020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961911","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e97020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961912","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"217020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961922","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Placement Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will write a 3000 word summary report describing their work placement experience in terms of the purpose and outcomes of the tasks/activities/project they were contributing to for the partner organisation. It will link to one of the required online modules and will be submitted on Moodle following the end of their placement within the organisation (dates flexible depending on Trimester structure[R1] ).

 

This formal report will include:

- Executive Summary

- Activity overview (e.g. context, rationale, aims, scope, time frame)

- Description of Methods (e.g. computing, field, lab techniques)

- Progress/Results/Findings

- Problems and Challenges

- References (if applicable)

 

Students will receive a rubric-based mark out of 50.

 

Students will receive feedback within one week of submission.

 

 [R1]Not sure how to word this as this will be offered for both normal Trimesters and intensive teaching periods

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e17020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961911","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e17020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961912","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e17020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e97020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961911","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e97020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961912","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"657020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961914","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Organisation Analysis Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will write a 1000 word report relating to organisational theory, behaviour, structure and practice as it applies to their placement partner organisation. This report relates to some specified SMART goals in one of the required online modules. It is due before the beginning of UNSW census week.  

 

Students will receive feedback from the course authority prior to census date with a final rubric assessment out of 20.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEES2680 - Introduction to science communication","description":"

Successful scientists - whether in the university environment or the outside workplace - have to be effective communicators. They have to craft their messages into different shapes for different audiences, whether writing a lecture, a report or research paper, or presenting to peers or public audiences.

This course seeks to provide science students with the opportunity to gain a solid foundation in necessary science communication skills. These include active listening, reading critically, writing succinctly in the narrative, descriptive and academic styles, the steps in essay writing for science topics, using grammar effectively, the anatomy of a compelling presentation in science and effective teamwork in group assignments.

Students also learn how to research science topics, including searching for and evaluating primary literature and in identifying academic-quality sources from non-academic sources on the internet.

For those students wishing to add a science communicator career option to their science degree, this course is also a foundation for the third level course BEES6800 The Science of Science Communication.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0e7020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f396198d","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Using writing skills for a science topic essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

Students provide a 1,500 word essay on a selected science-related topic. At the beginning of the essay, they dot-point the steps they took to research, outline, structure, draft and revise the essay (within the total word-count). The essay must demonstrate cohesion, coherence and clear, succinct construction. Students use primary literature and academic-level source references (not included in the word count). Active voice is encouraged. Students receive extensive feedback from Turnitin, where they submit their assignments.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"027020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961990","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c27020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961997","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Using presentation skills for a science topic Part A","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students storyboard a presentation on a science topic of their choice (800-1,200 words), including 2-3 example slides, and submit to Turnitin. Students receive extensive feedback via Turnitin. Students as a cohort also receive feedback through the course forum, where students can clarify their comprehension of the elements that create a compelling presentation. Referencing is encouraged without impact on the word count.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0a7020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f396198f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0a7020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961990","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c27020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f396199c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Using presentation skills for a science topic Part B","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students collaborate with other students to jointly produce a 3-minute slides-based presentation on a science topic selected from a list of options. Each student contributes slides with voice-over, and the group create a coherent presentation. The result is uploaded as an unlisted video to YouTube. Students should demonstrate collaboration within their group through the smooth transition in the presentation from one student to another within the group. Feedback to the group is through an email from teaching staff. Students can engage with teaching staff for further feedback.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"027020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0a7020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f396198f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0a7020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961990","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c67020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961992","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Three course questions utilising science communication skills","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

These three questions are exercises in reading, writing, and critical thinking skills that are science-related. The three questions are spread evenly through the course. All are written and submitted to Turnitin where students receive extensive feedback. Students can also engage in the course forum or directly with teaching staff for further feedback.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"027020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f396198f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ca7020dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961999","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/BEES2680.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEES2741 - Introduction to Astrobiology: Life in the Universe","description":"

Astrobiology is the study of the search for life elsewhere in the universe, the origin of life on Earth, and the future of life on Earth. This course has emerged from UNSW's Australian Centre for Astrobiology, which is deeply embedded in the search for life on Mars and the origin of life on Earth. This course is fully online and there is no final exam.


Students will get an overview of the interdisciplinary nature of astrobiology. The science ranges from our origin in the Big Bang at the beginning of the universe to the study of microbes that live in extreme environments on Earth, how life and our planet evolved together and the search for life elsewhere in our solar system and beyond. Astrobiology seeks to answer our most profound question: Are we alone in the universe?


This course addresses astrobiology at an intermediate level from the microbiological, geological and palaeobiological perspectives to the development of life on Earth and the search for life elsewhere in the universe. It is strongly interdisciplinary allow all science majors to view the relevance of other areas of science to their discipline. It also offers a possible pathway for a student to consider pursing their major within the astrobiology context.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e67060dbdbe5f450be4672f5f396190f","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Evolution of life and the planet","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Students partner with another student to investigate the evolution of life and the planet, and produce a three-minute video on the implications of this investigation for searching for life elsewhere in the universe. Students are expected to use primary literature and supply a separate list of references.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e67060dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ee7060dbdbe5f450be4672f5f396190f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"367060dbdbe5f450be4672f5f396191c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Proving that all life is related","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Completion of an adaptive e-learning virtual lab on extracting the 16S gene from the DNA of an unknown organism, comparing it to a database and placing it on the phylogenetic Tree of Life

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ee7060dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961910","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"667060dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961917","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Life elsewhere in the solar system","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

Students choose a possible planet or moon in the solar system (excluding Mars) and describe the research to date in a 1,500 word essay (excluding references and media). In particular they demonstrate how interdisciplinary science has resulted in the discoveries to date. Extensive use of primary literature is expected.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e67060dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e67060dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961911","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ee7060dbdbe5f450be4672f5f396190f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6a7060dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961912","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Origin of Earth's water","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students complete a 1,000 word essay (excluding references and media) comparing and contrasting the five main theories of the origin of water on Earth. Students are expected to demonstrate effective use of primary literature

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ee7060dbdbe5f450be4672f5f396190f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6e7060dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961919","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/BEES2741.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Astrobiology is the study of the search for life elsewhere in the universe, the origin of life on Earth, and the future of life on Earth. This course has emerged from UNSW's Australian Centre for Astrobiology, which is deeply embedded in the search for life on Mars and the origin of life on Earth. This course is fully online and there is no final exam.

Students will get an overview of the interdisciplinary nature of astrobiology. The science ranges from our origin in the Big Bang at the beginning of the universe to the study of microbes that live in extreme environments on Earth, how life and our planet evolved together and the search for life elsewhere in our solar system and beyond. Astrobiology seeks to answer our most profound question: Are we alone in the universe?

This course addresses astrobiology at an intermediate level from the microbiological, geological and palaeobiological perspectives to the development of life on Earth and the search for life elsewhere in the universe. It is strongly interdisciplinary allow all science majors to view the relevance of other areas of science to their discipline. It also offers a possible pathway for a student to consider pursing their major within the astrobiology context.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEES3041 - Big Data in the Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences","description":"

This is an advanced quantitative methods course which uses a project-based approach to consider the analysis, visualisation and communication of large and complex data sets. Students will choose a topic for in-depth instruction in one of the advanced quantitive research endeavours of the School of BEES. The modules cover techniques including meta-analyses, geographic data analyses, population and systems dynamics, phylogenetics and time series analyses.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9770a0dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961907","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Science communication","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Science communication. The first part of the assignment be the preparation of a popular science article (e.g. the Conversation) that summarises the importance, use, prospects of big data in the sub-discipline (module) that the student chooses. The second part of the assignment will be the development of an effective info-graphic to communicate main message from their project work.

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9370a0dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9b70a0dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961908","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1770a0dbdbe5f450be4672f5f396190b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

This assignment will require students to do a proposal that details their proposed methods for the major assignment (to summarise, analyse a big data set that is provided to them).

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9370a0dbdbe5f450be4672f5f396190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9b70a0dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961909","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"af70a0dbdbe5f450be4672f5f396190e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

A 24 UOC Research Project in the School of Biological, Earth & Environmental Sciences, taken in combination with BEES4522 and additional BEES Research Project courses to total 48 UOC. This course is only available to students enrolled in an Honours Program in the School of BEES and enrolment must be approved by the School of BEES Honours Coordinator. The course entails research in a defined disciplinary area (Archaeology & Palaeoenvironments, Biology, Climate Science, Ecology, Environmental Management, Genetics, Geochemistry, Geology, Human Geography, Marine and Coastal Science or Physical Geography) developed in consultation with an Honours Supervisor.


This course is only available to students enrolled in the School of BEES Honours Program.

contentlets.description:
A 24 UOC Research Project in the School of Biological, Earth & Environmental Sciences, taken in combination with BEES4522 and additional BEES Research Project courses to total 48 UOC. This course is only available to students enrolled in an Honours Program in the School of BEES and enrolment must be approved by the School of BEES Honours Coordinator. The course entails research in a defined disciplinary area (Archaeology & Palaeoenvironments, Biology, Climate Science, Ecology, Environmental Management, Genetics, Geochemistry, Geology, Human Geography, Marine and Coastal Science or Physical Geography) developed in consultation with an Honours Supervisor.

This course is only available to students enrolled in the School of BEES Honours Program.

contentlets.keywords: biological,earth & environmental science
contentlets.description:
A 18 UOC Research Project in the School of Biological, Earth & Environmental Sciences, taken in combination with BEES4522 and additional BEES Research Project courses to total 48 UOC. This course is only available to students enrolled in an Honours Program in the School of BEES and enrolment must be approved by the School of BEES Honours Coordinator. The course entails research in a defined disciplinary area (Archaeology & Palaeoenvironments, Biology, Climate Science, Ecology, Environmental Management, Genetics, Geochemistry, Geology, Human Geography, Marine and Coastal Science or Physical Geography) developed in consultation with an Honours Supervisor.

This course is only available to students enrolled in the School of BEES Honours Program.

A 16 UOC Research Project in the School of Biological, Earth & Environmental Sciences, in which students enrol three times for a total of 48 UOC. This course is only available to students enrolled in an Honours Program in the School of BEES and enrolment must be approved by the School of BEES Honours Coordinator. The course entails research in a defined disciplinary area (Archaeology & Palaeoenvironments, Biology, Climate Science, Ecology, Environmental Management, Geochemistry, Geology, Human Geography, Marine and Coastal Science or Physical Geography) developed in consultation with an Honours Supervisor.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a58064dbdbe5f450be4672f5f396192e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Seminar","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"5","description":"

The final seminar is worth 5% of overall Honours grade. Students will present a 5-minute seminar summarising their project.  Exact dates and times for the seminars will be released toward the end of the final term via emails.  Presentations cannot exceed 5 minutes, slides should be loaded up before the session begins.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e18064dbdbe5f450be4672f5f396192f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f18064dbdbe5f450be4672f5f3961930","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"398064dbdbe5f450be4672f5f396193b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thesis","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"82.5","description":"

Thesis is written in the format of a scientific paper, and the aim is to create a document as close as possible to ready for submission to a journal.

There is an absolute limit of 8,000 words of text (limit excludes tables, figures, references and any appendices, but includes in-text citations [e.g. “(Smith et al. 2019)”]). The Honours Coordinator may grant longer theses under exceptional circumstances (e.g., taxonomic treatments). Examiners (and practicing academic scientists more generally) expect a succinct document rather than a long discussion and so shorter theses will be welcomed.

All theses need to be submitted online via Moodle. They will be run through Turnitin, so avoid plagiarism.

Due Date will be announced on moodle, thesis is usually due week 9 in the last term.

The proposal must be student's own work, but should be developed with feedback from the supervisor.  A research proposal should demonstrate that the research question student's propose to investigate is interesting and important, and that the methods used are feasible and sound.  Due Date will be announced on moodle, proposal is usually due week 9 in the first term.

A 6UOC Research Project in the School of Biological, Earth & Environmental Sciences, taken in combinationwith BEES4522 and additional BEES Research Project courses to total 48 UOC. Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEES4523 - Research Proposal","description":"

This course is an essential component of the Honours Program in the School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences and is completed in the first session of an Honours Program. It is only available to students enrolled in an Honours Program offered by the School of BEES and enrolment must be approved by the School of BEES Honours Coordinator. The course assessment is  a research proposal that includes a literature review and risk assessment in a defined disciplinary area (including archaeology & palaeoenvironments, biology, climate science, ecology, environmental management, genetics, geochemistry, geology, human geography, marine & coastal science or physical geography). The course is taken in conjunction with an Honours Research Project in the School of BEES. The focus of the research proposal is decided in consultation with an Honours Supervisor and is related to the topic area of the research project.

Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"BEES5041","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEES5041 - Data Analysis: Environmental Science & Management","description":"

Development of skills in applying statistics to biological, earth and spatial data; design and analysis of experiments in life and earth sciences; sampling strategies for estimating sample size; analysis of community and environment structure using multivariate statistics; simulation modelling in population biology, and statistical fitting of non-linear models to population growth data; correlation and both simple and multiple regression; improving statistical models using analysis of residuals; analysis of spatial data. Examples are drawn from ecological, geographical, earth, behavioural, and genetic and immunological data. Practical work emphasis on problem-solving and hands-on experience with EXCEL, MINITAB and other specialist software.


Assumed knowledge: MATH1041 or relevant undergraduate level of statistical analysis.

This report is based on practical material covered during the labs in weeks 1-3. Students are required to conduct and interpret of statistical tests run in the practical classes, and they are assessed on their ability to perform these tasks correctly. Feedback from academic staff is provided within two weeks of submission, in the form of marks and written comments.

This report is based on practical material covered during the labs, and analyses of data collected during the field trip. Students are required to conduct and interpret of statistical tests run in the practical classes, and they are assessed on their ability to perform these tasks correctly. They are also assessed on their ability to effectively communicate results of the data collected from field trip. Feedback from academic staff is provided within two weeks of submission, in the form of marks and written comments.

\n

This report is based on practical material covered during the labs, and and independent analysis of a data set provided. Students are required to conduct and interpret of statistical tests run in the practical classes, and they are assessed on their ability to perform these tasks correctly. They are also assessed on their ability to effectively communicate results of their analyses of data provided. Feedback from academic staff is provided within two weeks of submission, in the form of marks and written comments.

\n

contentlets.keywords: biological,earth & environmental science,marine science and management,data analysis,statistical analysis
contentlets.description:
Development of skills in applying statistics to biological, earth and spatial data; design and analysis of experiments in life and earth sciences; sampling strategies for estimating sample size; analysis of community and environment structure using multivariate statistics; simulation modelling in population biology, and statistical fitting of non-linear models to population growth data; correlation and both simple and multiple regression; improving statistical models using analysis of residuals; analysis of spatial data. Examples are drawn from ecological, geographical, earth, behavioural, and genetic and immunological data. Practical work emphasis on problem-solving and hands-on experience with EXCEL, MINITAB and other specialist software.

Assumed knowledge: MATH1041 or relevant undergraduate level of statistical analysis.
contentlets.title: Data Analysis: Environmental Science & Management

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEES6601 - An Introduction to the Sydney Environment","description":"

!Important! This course is not available to students who are taking Majors in the School of BEES.  The course will not count towards to your BEES major.


This course provides an introduction to the physical, biological and social environment of Sydney.  Topics include the geophysical environment, the Indigenous people of Sydney, the natural and biological hazards of Sydney and the development of Sydney into a global city. The course also consists of a series of workshops which consider the contemporary environmental issues facing Sydney. A series of optional field visit(s) are designed to introduce the diversity of Sydney's biophysical environment.


Note: Students have the option of participating in field visits and students may incur personal expenses. Details will be provided during the first week of the course.



 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"40b0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b1","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Workshop Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"15","description":"

In the first meetings all students are allocated to a specific question relating to a subsequent workshop. They must come to this class with a presentation and be prepared to lead the discussion. Their role in leading the discussion is peer assessed: the tutor assesses the presentation. Although all allocated students must attend with a presentation, only a random selection is actually presented    


The actual presentation is assessed by academic staff and will be marked with feedback.

\n

The class discussion will be peer assessed, based on a rubric described by the workshop convenor.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ccb0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ccb0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"14b0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619bc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Workshop Reports","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

These are based on the blended learning model: in the case where students are expected to have prepared for a class (e.g. watched video material etc) there will be a simple pre-class task (up to a maximum of 4).    


These will be simple 'pre-lab' type exercises with marks provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c4b0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ccb0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ccb0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"14b0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619c3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":null,"learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ccb0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ccb0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1cb0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619bf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field Report or Alternative Assessment Task","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"Not specified","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c4b0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ccb0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ccb0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"40b0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Assessment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

This exercise is designed for students to reflect on their preconceived ideas, initial perceptions (and surprises) and what they learnt about Sydney over the course. We will set this up in Moodle such that there is a discussion forum and students will be required to make observations through time.


There will be an allocated mark for their observations through time, participation in online discussion, but most of the assessment will result from a final assignment, which will be marked and returned to the student.

!Important! This course is not available to students who are taking Majors in the School of BEES.  The course will not count towards to your BEES major.


This course provides an introduction to the physical, biological and social environment of Sydney.  Topics include the geophysical environment, the Indigenous people of Sydney, the natural and biological hazards of Sydney and the development of Sydney into a global city. The course also consists of a series of workshops which consider the contemporary environmental issues facing Sydney. A series of optional field visit(s) are designed to introduce the diversity of Sydney's biophysical environment.


Note: Students have the option of participating in field visits and students may incur personal expenses. Details will be provided during the first week of the course.



 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"40b0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b1","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Workshop Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"15","description":"

In the first meetings all students are allocated to a specific question relating to a subsequent workshop. They must come to this class with a presentation and be prepared to lead the discussion. Their role in leading the discussion is peer assessed: the tutor assesses the presentation. Although all allocated students must attend with a presentation, only a random selection is actually presented    


The actual presentation is assessed by academic staff and will be marked with feedback.

\n

The class discussion will be peer assessed, based on a rubric described by the workshop convenor.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ccb0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ccb0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"14b0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619bc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Workshop Reports","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

These are based on the blended learning model: in the case where students are expected to have prepared for a class (e.g. watched video material etc) there will be a simple pre-class task (up to a maximum of 4).    


These will be simple 'pre-lab' type exercises with marks provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c4b0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ccb0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ccb0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"14b0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619c3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":null,"learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ccb0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ccb0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1cb0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619bf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field Report or Alternative Assessment Task","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"Not specified","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c4b0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ccb0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ccb0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"40b0e01fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619b5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Assessment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

This exercise is designed for students to reflect on their preconceived ideas, initial perceptions (and surprises) and what they learnt about Sydney over the course. We will set this up in Moodle such that there is a discussion forum and students will be required to make observations through time.


There will be an allocated mark for their observations through time, participation in online discussion, but most of the assessment will result from a final assignment, which will be marked and returned to the student.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEES6741 - Astrobiology: Life in the Universe","description":"

Astrobiology is the study of life in the universe and the chemistry, physics, and adaptations that influence its origin, evolution and destiny. It is an interdisciplinary science encompassing aspects of biology, chemistry, geology and astronomy.


This technology-enabled fully online third level science elective course includes short video talks from specialists in these fields embedded and other short video presentations embedded into an electronic book each week threaded with engaging narrative on this interesting subject. Students have the opportunity of participating in an interactive Virtual Field Trip experience, and engaging forum discussion.


Through these media, students will learn how life is strongly coupled with its environment and the implications for the search for life on other worlds in our solar system and beyond. They will learn how evidence of life can be found in the geological record on Earth, how the oxygenation of the Earth gave rise to complex life, how evolution is demonstrated, and why the search for evidence of extraterrestrial life - whether microbial or intelligent - is important to our understanding of our place in space.


Electronic book topics will cover the origin of life and its philosophical implications, extremophiles, the Tree of Life, fossil records, the history and evolution of Earth and its biosphere, the interactions of life and its environment, the bid to find Earth-like extra-solar planets, planetary and galactic habitable zones, searching for life on Mars and beyond, and more.


Students from all science disciplines are encouraged to consider this course providing they have completed 48 units of credit in science. Interdisciplinary tutorials are provided each week to ensure all students have the same basic knowledge of any particular discipline.


From 2019, term planning makes it possible to take the second level course BEES2741: Introduction to astrobiology: Life in the universe in the term prior to BEES6741.


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"bcb0241fdbe5f450be4672f5f396197e","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Astrobiology topic","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Assignment 1 is a 1,000 word essay, excluding references and media, on an astrobiology topic (changes with each year's presentation). It is aimed at providing students with the opportunity for critical analysis and the use of primary literature.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b8b0241fdbe5f450be4672f5f3961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b8b0241fdbe5f450be4672f5f3961981","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"70b0241fdbe5f450be4672f5f3961983","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Virtual Field Trip","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students prepare for an interactive Virtual Field Trip developed for the course (VFT development completed and tested in past presentations of the course). They use primary literature and plan for the virtual field trip to the Pilbara of Western Australia where we find the most convincing evidence of life on Earth 3.5 billion years ago. Students visit 12 sites in an ancient collapsed caldera looking for evidence that supports the proposition that this was a hydrothermal system supporting living organisms billions of years ago. They make a table of the evidence they collect individually, and explain why they collected each sample. They then partner with another student so they can collectively interpret the environment from their evidence. They produce a 3-minute video (slides and voice-over recommended) to provide their interpretation. Marks are split 15% for the table of evidence and 15% for the video.

contentlets.keywords: biological,earth & environmental science,astrobiology,space exploration,origin of life,interdisciplinary research,effective communication
contentlets.description:
Astrobiology is the study of life in the universe and the chemistry, physics, and adaptations that influence its origin, evolution and destiny. It is an interdisciplinary science encompassing aspects of biology, chemistry, geology and astronomy.

This technology-enabled fully online third level science elective course includes short video talks from specialists in these fields embedded and other short video presentations embedded into an electronic book each week threaded with engaging narrative on this interesting subject. Students have the opportunity of participating in an interactive Virtual Field Trip experience, and engaging forum discussion.

Through these media, students will learn how life is strongly coupled with its environment and the implications for the search for life on other worlds in our solar system and beyond. They will learn how evidence of life can be found in the geological record on Earth, how the oxygenation of the Earth gave rise to complex life, how evolution is demonstrated, and why the search for evidence of extraterrestrial life - whether microbial or intelligent - is important to our understanding of our place in space.

Electronic book topics will cover the origin of life and its philosophical implications, extremophiles, the Tree of Life, fossil records, the history and evolution of Earth and its biosphere, the interactions of life and its environment, the bid to find Earth-like extra-solar planets, planetary and galactic habitable zones, searching for life on Mars and beyond, and more.

Students from all science disciplines are encouraged to consider this course providing they have completed 48 units of credit in science. Interdisciplinary tutorials are provided each week to ensure all students have the same basic knowledge of any particular discipline.

From 2019, term planning makes it possible to take the second level course BEES2741: Introduction to astrobiology: Life in the universe in the term prior to BEES6741.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"bcb0241fdbe5f450be4672f5f396197e","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Astrobiology topic","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Assignment 1 is a 1,000 word essay, excluding references and media, on an astrobiology topic (changes with each year's presentation). It is aimed at providing students with the opportunity for critical analysis and the use of primary literature.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b8b0241fdbe5f450be4672f5f3961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b8b0241fdbe5f450be4672f5f3961981","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"70b0241fdbe5f450be4672f5f3961983","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Virtual Field Trip","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students prepare for an interactive Virtual Field Trip developed for the course (VFT development completed and tested in past presentations of the course). They use primary literature and plan for the virtual field trip to the Pilbara of Western Australia where we find the most convincing evidence of life on Earth 3.5 billion years ago. Students visit 12 sites in an ancient collapsed caldera looking for evidence that supports the proposition that this was a hydrothermal system supporting living organisms billions of years ago. They make a table of the evidence they collect individually, and explain why they collected each sample. They then partner with another student so they can collectively interpret the environment from their evidence. They produce a 3-minute video (slides and voice-over recommended) to provide their interpretation. Marks are split 15% for the table of evidence and 15% for the video.

They then suggest a simple experiment that could test that research question. Students must use primary literature in formulating their question. The essay length can be 2,000-2,500 words (excluding references).

Environmental changes and their impacts are increasingly providing valuable insights into how our planet works. This course provides practical training in environmental changes (from the past through to present day) and runs principally as an intensive one (1) week course in the Queenstown (South Island, New Zealand). Students will receive practical training in field-based sampling of environmental-human archives to better understand extinctions, natural hazards, climate change, Indigenous Knowledge and invasive alien species (IAS).

This is the major assignment associated with this course: it will consist of a 3 minute video document explaining one of the research topics explored during the field work.

Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"BEES6800","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEES6800 - The Science of Science Communication","description":"

The Science of Science Communication course aims to teach science students how to effectively communicate across a range of audiences why science matters, how it works, and what the relevance of science is to the way we live our lives. Students will learn to do that effectively in a digital age where the content is easily accessed but the understanding of that information is harder to achieve. They will also learn how to measure the effectiveness of their communication of science. Understanding the art of evidence based science communication has become more important than ever before in a world where fake science news threatens our ability to communicate science effectively.


For those students going on to a higher degree in science, a basic requirement of being a successful scientist is to be able to effectively communicate. However, very few scientists have had any formal evidence-based science communication education. Fewer still have been taught how new emerging communication technologies can engage audiences with science or how to use emotion and be personable when communicating science. This course prepares students for a career in their chosen science discipline.


The objective of BEES6800 is to help students to gain confidence in clearly communicating science and why it matters across multiple peer and public audiences in multiple modes, and via multiple digital technologies and media – including social media.


The course is fully online.


Assessment will be through three connected online assignments that directly address course outcomes.These outcomes include understanding the nature and processes of science, being able to communicate science clearly with multiple audiences in multiple modes, understanding the best use of new and emerging technologies to communicate science, thinking critically and creatively, and knowing how to measure the effectiveness of science communication.


There is no final exam.


Students need 48 Units of Credit to take this science elective course. There is no assumed knowledge of science communication.


Students taking this course will be able to communicate effectively as scientists, and may find it useful if considering a career in science communication.


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"fab0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619d9","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assignment 3","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Students prepare and justify a plan for a research centre to engage with the public through social media. The assignment has three parts. First, students produce an outline of a social media plan (600 words, worth 10% of the course marks and due in Week 8) to receive feedback before proceeding to the final plan. They then produce the final plan (1,500 words and worth 30% of the course marks) together with a sample of a posting (150-300 words worth 10% of the course marks) due in Week 10.

\n

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f2b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"f2b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"f2b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619dc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f2b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fab0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"fab0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fab0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619dc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"43b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619e3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Assignment 1 is a 1,500-word news article on a subject that explores the communication of the nature and processes of science, probability, risk and uncertainty. This assignment is due in week 4. Feedback in the form of comments via Turnitin in week 6.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f2b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"f2b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619dc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fab0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619dc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"76b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619de","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Assignment 2 is a 3-minute video with the public as the target audience. The video must use a public accessible object like the six-sided perfect symmetry of a snowflake or the flickering of a candle to use as a metaphor or analogy to weave an engaging story about science. Students must also submit appropriate referencing both in the subject of the story and in science communication. The assignment is due in week 7. Feedback via email to each individual student. Additional one-on-one feedback available electronically or face-to-face in week 9.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f2b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"f2b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619dc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f2b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fab0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"fab0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fab0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619dc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"83b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619ec","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/BEES6800.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEES6800 - The Science of Science Communication","description":"

The Science of Science Communication course aims to teach science students how to effectively communicate across a range of audiences why science matters, how it works, and what the relevance of science is to the way we live our lives. Students will learn to do that effectively in a digital age where the content is easily accessed but the understanding of that information is harder to achieve. They will also learn how to measure the effectiveness of their communication of science. Understanding the art of evidence based science communication has become more important than ever before in a world where fake science news threatens our ability to communicate science effectively.


For those students going on to a higher degree in science, a basic requirement of being a successful scientist is to be able to effectively communicate. However, very few scientists have had any formal evidence-based science communication education. Fewer still have been taught how new emerging communication technologies can engage audiences with science or how to use emotion and be personable when communicating science. This course prepares students for a career in their chosen science discipline.


The objective of BEES6800 is to help students to gain confidence in clearly communicating science and why it matters across multiple peer and public audiences in multiple modes, and via multiple digital technologies and media – including social media.


The course is fully online.


Assessment will be through three connected online assignments that directly address course outcomes.These outcomes include understanding the nature and processes of science, being able to communicate science clearly with multiple audiences in multiple modes, understanding the best use of new and emerging technologies to communicate science, thinking critically and creatively, and knowing how to measure the effectiveness of science communication.


There is no final exam.


Students need 48 Units of Credit to take this science elective course. There is no assumed knowledge of science communication.


Students taking this course will be able to communicate effectively as scientists, and may find it useful if considering a career in science communication.


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"fab0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619d9","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assignment 3","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Students prepare and justify a plan for a research centre to engage with the public through social media. The assignment has three parts. First, students produce an outline of a social media plan (600 words, worth 10% of the course marks and due in Week 8) to receive feedback before proceeding to the final plan. They then produce the final plan (1,500 words and worth 30% of the course marks) together with a sample of a posting (150-300 words worth 10% of the course marks) due in Week 10.

\n

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f2b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"f2b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"f2b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619dc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f2b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fab0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"fab0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fab0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619dc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"43b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619e3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Assignment 1 is a 1,500-word news article on a subject that explores the communication of the nature and processes of science, probability, risk and uncertainty. This assignment is due in week 4. Feedback in the form of comments via Turnitin in week 6.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f2b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"f2b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619dc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fab0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619dc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"76b0a41fdbe5f450be4672f5f39619de","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Assignment 2 is a 3-minute video with the public as the target audience. The video must use a public accessible object like the six-sided perfect symmetry of a snowflake or the flickering of a candle to use as a metaphor or analogy to weave an engaging story about science. Students must also submit appropriate referencing both in the subject of the story and in science communication. The assignment is due in week 7. Feedback via email to each individual student. Additional one-on-one feedback available electronically or face-to-face in week 9.

Students Only)","description":"

The course covers essential skills needed in biological research and subsequent employment. Principal topics covered include presentation skills (written, oral, and audiovisual including computer-aided presentations), database and library usage, information retrieval and usage of major computer packages as well as more specific research skills which may be tailored to particular interest groups. The course must be taken by all commencing postgraduate students in the School of Biological Science unless they have already passed BEES4511.


Note: Required for enrolment in this course: enrolment in a postgraduate research program in a biological discipline within UNSW, or completion of requirements for Honours in Biology or other discipline area.

The course covers essential skills needed in biological research and subsequent employment. Principal topics covered include presentation skills (written, oral, and audiovisual including computer-aided presentations), database and library usage, information retrieval and usage of major computer packages as well as more specific research skills which may be tailored to particular interest groups. The course must be taken by all commencing postgraduate students in the School of Biological Science unless they have already passed BEES4511.

Note: Required for enrolment in this course: enrolment in a postgraduate research program in a biological discipline within UNSW, or completion of requirements for Honours in Biology or other discipline area.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BEES9041 - Big Data in the Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences","description":"

This is a post graduate quantitative methods course which uses a project-based approach to consider the analysis, visualisation and communication of large and complex data sets.  Students will choose a topic for in-depth instruction in one of the advanced quantitative research endeavors in the School of BEES.  The modules cover approaches including (but not limited to) meta-analysis, geographic data analysis, population and systems dynamics, phylogenetics and time series analyses.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7af3d3b2dba4b450fe4b322af4961946","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Final report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

This assessment is the largest of the four assessments. It consists of 3 components: 1) a scientific report (45%), 2) a computer script (code; 10%) and 3) a dataset & metadata (5%). The latter two components are supplementary materials to your scientific report, which will be written as a scientific research paper. To complete this assessment in a timely manner, students will need good project management, one of the most important skills to learn via this course. The final report is due in week 10 and feedback will be provided within two weeks

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"78b61776dba4b450fe4b322af496195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8f7453b2dba4b450fe4b322af4961985","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d9665f36dba4b450fe4b322af49619f5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6ed242a3dba07850fe4b322af496193f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Science communication assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

The first part of the assignment will be the preparation of a popular science article (e.g., the Conversation) that summarises the importance, use, and prospects of big data in the sub-disciplines (module) that the student chooses. The second part of the assignment will be the development of effective info-graphics to communicate the main message from their project work in the form of a Twitter thread (i.e., a Twitter conference presentation).  This assessment will take place in week 10 and feedback will be provided within two weeks.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"78b61776dba4b450fe4b322af496195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d9665f36dba4b450fe4b322af49619f5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9eb3c2a3dba07850fe4b322af496195a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Final presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Via this assessment, students will demonstrate their ability to communicate scientific results as an oral presentation to an audience. Students will give a 10-min presentation to the class, followed by ~4-min question time. Their ability to answer questions as well as present their project effectively will be assessed. The presentations will be in week 10 and comments will be returned in one week.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"78b61776dba4b450fe4b322af496195d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e75342a3dba07850fe4b322af4961943","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Reseach Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

This assessment will require students to create a detailed proposal of their ‘big data’ project. This will take a form of a scientific manuscript with an abstract, introduction and method (i.e., in a form of pre-registration or a registered report stage 1). Students will learn to plan their scientific project.  This assessment is due in week 5 and feedback will be provided one week later.  In addition, students will meet with course academics starting in week 2 for formative feedback on their proposal ideas.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8f7453b2dba4b450fe4b322af4961985","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dc06dff2dba4b450fe4b322af49619b5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ed67d3b6dba4b450fe4b322af49619b8","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/BEES9041.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}
